history.content:
<md>I really hope they expand too ... Here's a list of classes made a 106 TA when we were concerned about enrollment some time ago.

-------

**I can't get into the course. What are some alternative course options?**

Some related courses are:

\- ~~EE C128 / ME C134: Feedback control systems. If you haven't taken a similar course before, I highly recommend this. The course also covers a number of frequency-based control design methods that no other course at Berkeley really covers (even at the graduate level).~~ Doesn't look like this is offered upcoming Fall

\- EECS 149: Embedded Systems. This course is much lower level (closer to hardware) robotics. You'll be learning about microcontrollers and RTOS stuff that we don't cover.

\- ME 136: Intro to UAVs. This course covers a reasonable amount of the same theoretical material. The labs are quite different, but still very fun and informative.

\- ~~ME 193B: Feedback Control of Legged Robotics. This course is purely theoretical / software driven, and at a much higher level than 106A (closer to 106B), but the material is very interesting.~~ Also not offered in Fall

**Can I take 106B without 106A?**

If you're a grad student with some background in robotics, there's a pretty good chance you'll be fine. If you're an undergrad, there's a pretty good chance you'll struggle. In the past three years, I'm pretty sure that every undergrad who's tried to take 106B without 106A has dropped (I think this is still true...), though if you have an unusually strong background you're welcome to try.

----

I would probably add onto this by recommending CS 188, ME 102B, and of course your foundational courses EE 120, 126, 127. Looks like 128 isn't taught next semester which is a shame. There's plenty you can do on your own to get involved with robotics; if you clarify where your interests lie between research and industry I (and others) can try to provide more help.</md>

-------

**I can't get into the course. What are some alternative course options?**

Some related courses are (I removed the ones that aren't offered, which narrowed down the list):

\- EECS 149: Embedded Systems. This course is much lower level (closer to hardware) robotics. You'll be learning about microcontrollers and RTOS stuff that we don't cover.

\- ME 136: Intro to UAVs. This course covers a reasonable amount of the same theoretical material. The labs are quite different, but still very fun and informative.

**Can I take 106B without 106A?**

In the past three years, I'm pretty sure that every undergrad who's tried to take 106B without 106A has dropped (I think this is still true...), though if you have an unusually strong background you're welcome to try.

----

I would probably add onto this by recommending CS 188, ME 102B, and of course your foundational courses EE 120, 126, 127. Looks like 128 isn't taught next semester which is a shame. There's plenty you can do on your own to get involved with robotics; if you clarify where your interests lie between research and industry I (and others) can try to provide more help.)</md>

children.subject: <md>I wouldn't say this is an alternative at all, but there are decals that introduce you to robotics, one of which is hosted by IEEE and is called Micromouse. It basically lets you build and program autonomous maze-solving cars and gives you exposure to Arduinos and EE skills. Definitely not a replacement but I'd say a good introduction to the field! </md>

<md>For 106B, we expect students to come in with understanding of chapters 2, 3, and the first half of chapter 4 of the [MLS textbook](http://www.docjava.com/posterous/file/2012/04/8971919-mls94-complete.pdf), be familiar with controls and systems through recommended experience of the 16B -> EE120/ME132 -> EE128/ME134 level (although the first two are probably good enough, or even just 16B if you remember everything well enough), and to be comfortable making projects with ROS.</md>
If you're an instructor for this class, what do you think are the chances it expands its capacity further?
<md>Lol I have no idea, but we will be trying</md>

history.content: Since 106A looks like it's closed (i really hope they add seats), what's the best alternative to 106A to get into the robotics field or at least prepare for it?
history.subject: Best Alternative to EECS106A
